children.name: be in b1
children.definition: be in if sb is in, they are in their home and you can visit them or talk to them on thephone:ở nhà
examples: ‘hello, mrs jones. is sally in, please?’
we went to see phil and tony but there was nobody in.
no, gerry won’t be in until after eight o'clock.

children.name: be at home a1
children.definition: be/ stay at home ở nhà
examples: i’ll be at home tonight if you want to call me.
we’re just going to stay at home rather than go away anywhere.

children.name: be home a1
children.definition: be/ stay home ở nhà
examples: jim’s never home friday nights. you should know that.
it was raining, so i stayed home.
be home alonehome on your own, used especially aboutchildren
the two-year-old girl had been left home alone.

children.name: my mother's x
children.definition: jerry’s/ my mother’s/ the carters’ etcspokenthe place where jerry, my mother, the carters etc live: nhà của ...
examples: ok. i’ll see you at helen’s at eight o'clock.
we were at the thompsons’ last saturday for dinner.
you’ve never been to my sister’s, have you?

children.name: home a1
children.definition: home  the place where you live:
examples: people like to feel secure in their own homes.
buying your first home is a very important step.
family homethe house where a family has lived for a long time
to raise the extra money they had to sell the family home.
home lifethe things you do at home
you need to maintain a good balance between your home life and career.

children.name: place a2
children.definition: placespokeninformal the house, apartment etc where someone lives:nơi ở
examples: terry’s just bought himself a place over in newgate, overlooking the harbour.
sb’s place
why don’t you come around to our place for a drink on saturday?
your place is too small for a party. let’s have it at mine.

children.name: address a1
children.definition: address the number of the house or building, and the name of the street, road and town where sb lives:
examples: what’s your address and telephone number?
change of addresswhen you move to a different address
notify your credit card company of any change of address.
address booka list of addresses of your friends, family etc
i checked my address book for rick’s house number.

children.name: residence c2
children.definition: residence formal sb’s home, especially the home of an important person, that is sometimes used for official dinners, meetings etc:
examples: 10 downing street is the british prime minister’s official residence.
we first met at a cocktail party at the residence of the russian ambassador.
the governor'sofficialresidence

children.name: nest x
children.definition: nest a comfortable home : tổ ấm
examples: when the children grow up andleave thenest

children.name: to not be in your home
be away a2
children.definition: be away to not be in your home for several days, weeks, or months: xa nhà
examples: who’s going to look after your cats while you’re away?
be away from
jack worked as a pilot and was often away from home.

children.name: be out a2
children.definition: be out especiallyspokento not be in your home for a short period: ra ngoài , không ở nhà
examples: ‘can i speak to frank?’ ‘i’m sorry he’s out right now.’
while they were out, someone broke in and stole their tv and vcr.

children.name: a place where you can stay when working or studying near there
sw to stay u
children.definition: a place to stay/ sw to stay especiallyspokena place where you can stay, for example a hotel or a room in sb’s house:
examples: she needs somewhere to stay while she’s at college.
if i can’t find a place to stay, maybe i could stay at your pad.

children.name: lodgings x
children.definition: lodgingsuka housewhere you pay rent to the people who own it so that you can live in one of their rooms:nơi trọ
examples: the henstocks were lucky enough to find lodgings in the village while they awaited a new home
she’s going to stay in lodgings until she finds a place of her own.
board and lodgingswhen the price you pay includes some or all of your mealsviệc ăn ở trọ
she was given free board and lodgings at the school where she worked.

children.name: boarding house x
children.definition: boarding house aprivatehouse where you pay to sleep and eat, and where you stay for a short time:nhà trọ
examples: he took two rooms in a private boarding house.
some of the boarding houses we stayed in were really run-down.

children.name: digs x
children.definition: digsukinformala room in a house that you pay rent for, especially temporarily, for example because you are astudent:phòng trọ
examples: in our third year at university, we moved into digs in elm street.

children.name: happening or doing sth in sb’s home
at home a1
children.definition: at home
examples: the good thing about my job is that i can often work at home.
earlier in the century it was normal for women to have their babies at home.
darren still lives at home with his parents.

children.name: domestic b2
children.definition: domestic happening in or relating to the home:
examples: she likes to keep her domestic life quite separate from her work.
the women had all experienced some form of domestic violence.

children.name: home x
children.definition: home designed to be used in homes: trong nhà
examples: the company has decided to expand in the home computer market.
home furnishings are on the second floor next to the toy department.

children.name: domestic b2
children.definition: domestic designed to be used in homes, rather than in factories, offices, or other public places: trong nhà
examples: the gas is used for domestic heating and cooking.
the store sells a wide range of domestic appliances.

children.name: home a1
children.definition: home
examples: go/ come/ arrive etc home
he cleans the offices after all the workers have gone home.
come straight home after the theatre, won’t you?
bring/ take sth home
you can take the laptop home with you if you like.

children.name: a place for sb to live
accommodation b1
children.definition: accommodationformala place where people can live or stay, including houses, flats, hotels etc:chỗ ở, chốn ở
examples: the holiday costs about £400 for a week’s accommodation and flights.
student/rented/holiday etc accommodation
i’ve been looking in the newspapers for student accommodation but it’s all so expensive.

children.name: a roof over your head c2
children.definition: a roof over your headinformala place to live - use this especially when you arecomparing this with the possibility of not having anywhere to live at all:nơi ở
examples: it doesn’t matter what kind of place it is, at least you’ll have a roof over your head.
it’s hard to be cheerful when you haven’t even got a roof over your head.
she gave him enough money to get a roof over his head.

children.name: sw to live a1
children.definition: sw to live a place where you can live - use this especially when this isdifficulttoget:nơi để sống
examples: i’ll stay at my grandmother’s at first, until i find somewhere to live.
students looking for somewhere to live can go the university accommodation service.

children.name: home x
children.definition: home a house, flat etc for people to live in - used especially inadvertisementsor totalk about large numbers of homes:nhà
examples: they want to build forty luxury homes on a disused railway site.
between 1945 and 1970 the government built 110,000 new homes for low-paid workers.

children.name: residential c2
children.definition: residentiala residential job, position, course, etc. is one for which you live at the same place where you work or study.

children.name: premises c1
children.definition: premises the buildings and land that a shop, restaurant, company etc uses : cơ ngơi
examples: schools may earn extra money by renting out their premises.
business premises
off the premises
the manager escorted him off the premises.
the security guards escorted the protestersoff(= away from) the premises.
on the premises
the wonderful desserts are made on the premises.
the ice cream is madeon thepremises (= in the building where it is sold) .

children.name: door-to-door x
children.definition: door-to-door visiting each house in a street or area, usually to sell sth, collect money, or ask for votes :
examples: a door-to-door salesman
he was a door-to-doorsalesmanbefore he became an actor.
she sells cosmetics door-to-door.

children.name: to not be in your home at night
stay out b2
children.definition: stay out to not come home at night, or to go home late
examples: our cat usually stays out at night.
my mum won't let me stay outlate.
